channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Closed Campuses, So College Tours Moved Online
item.description: Colleges are ghost towns, but officials are trying to reach prospective students with virtual visits and Zoom meetings. Can they replicate that face-to-face feeling?
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: When the Yale University campus closed in March, the admissions team moved quickly to shift its programming online.

item.title: Rhode Island Pushes Aggressive Testing, a Move That Could Ease Reopening
item.description: The state has seen a rise in cases of the coronavirus, in part, experts say, because it is testing more than many states.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:description: Rhode Island’s first walk-up coronavirus testing site opened last week, in Providence.

item.title: Texas and Other States Reopening: A Confusing Patchwork
item.description: Several states, including Texas and Florida, have stay-at-home orders expiring this week. “That executive order has done its job to slow the growth of Covid-19,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Manny Fernandez and Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jose Oregel, owner of The Bar.Ber.Shop in Greeley, Colo., resumed cutting hair on Monday, but he said he was “confused” about the new rules.

item.title: Houston’s ‘Horrifying’ Double Crisis: Oil Crash and Virus Shutdown
item.description: Houston has been reeling from oil-market chaos on top of a coronavirus shutdown. Job losses could reach 300,000.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:description: People lined up in their cars to receive food at a distribution site in Houston this month.

item.title: The Pentagon Released U.F.O. Videos. Don’t Hold Your Breath for a Breakthrough.
item.description: On Monday, the Department of Defense formally released three Navy videos that contain “unidentified aerial phenomena.” Enthusiasts were encouraged, though there was nothing new.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: JetBlue Is the First Major U.S. Airline to Require Masks for Passengers
item.description: The airline will require all passengers to wear a face covering from the beginning to the end of their trip. The policy takes effect Monday.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: JetBlue will require passengers to cover their mouths and noses at check-in, boarding and for the duration of their flight.

item.title: Watch Live: Hillary Clinton Endorses Joe Biden for President
item.description: The announcement by the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee follows ones from Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren as the party tries to show its unity.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Maggie Astor
item.media:description: With an expected endorsement of Joseph R. Biden Jr., Hillary Clinton is the latest party leader to try to make a case for returning the White House to Democratic hands in November.

item.title: Former Aides to Bernie Sanders Form a Super PAC to Support Joe Biden
item.description: Mr. Sanders’s 2016 campaign manager and another architect of the 2016 bid are joining together in an effort to rally progressive support for the former vice president ahead of the November election.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.category: Future To Believe In PAC (Political Organization)
item.media:description: Jeff Weaver, a former top aide and campaign manager for Senator Bernie Sanders, is helping form a new super PAC to support Joe Biden’s presidential bid.

item.title: Making Theater Essential, Digitally
item.description: The Homebound Project convenes 50 actors and playwrights to raise money for a project combating childhood hunger.
item.dc:creator: Devi Lockwood
item.media:credit: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catya McMullen, a playwright, who helped to create the Homebound Project along with the stage director Jenna Worsham.

item.title: Coronavirus and Race: Black and Latino People Are California's Most Vulnerable
item.description: Tuesday: Dr. Sonia Angell, the state’s public health director, discusses troubling trends. Also: A remembrance of a Riverside County deputy.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A surfer made his way into the waves as a man walked his dog on Monday in San Diego. The city opened its beaches to surfing, running and walking, but sitting at the beach remains prohibited.

item.title: Trump’s Response to Virus Reflects a Long Disregard for Science
item.description: The president’s Covid-19 response has extended the administration’s longstanding practice of undermining scientific expertise for political purposes.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump arrived at the White House daily coronavirus briefing this month.

item.title: On Politics: How Available Is Virus Aid, Really?
item.description: Rising complaints from governors, and some Supreme Court news: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Coronavirus, Texas, Paycheck Protection Program: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tattoo parlor in Greeley, Colo., on Monday. States are beginning to reopen a patchwork of businesses.

item.title: Coronavirus Live News Updates
item.description: At least a dozen states forged ahead with strategies to ease restrictions. After complaints, House Democratic leaders delayed members’ return to Washington.

item.title: Women at a Marine Boot Camp Represent an Identity Crisis for the Corps
item.description: Keeping men and women in separate platoons during recruit training is the last stand for the Marine Corps, which has been slow to move toward gender integration.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Hilary Swift
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island (SC)
item.media:description: Recruits at Parris Island shouted “no brass, no trash, no live rounds” while getting checked for weapons after a drill.

item.title: How a Digital Ad Strategy That Helped Trump Is Being Used Against Him
item.description: A former Facebook employee is using a tool he employed to help President Trump win to conduct tests for a progressive group, Acronym, dedicated to ousting Mr. Trump from office.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The office of the progressive nonprofit group Acronym in Washington in 2019.

item.title: Fired in a Pandemic ‘Because We Tried to Start a Union,’ Workers Say
item.description: Employees who were in unions or pushing to join them have been laid off and replaced by nonunionized labor. It’s part of a pattern stretching back decades, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams
item.media:credit: Ben Solomon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cort Furniture Rental warehouse in North Bergen, N.J., where employees were let go shortly before a unionization vote was to take place.

item.title: Ohio’s G.O.P. Governor Splits From Trump, and Rises in Popularity
item.description: Mike DeWine, a low-key career politician, has followed health experts’ guidance as Ohio confronts the coronavirus. His constituents are overwhelmingly appreciative.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Doral Chenoweth/The Columbus Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Mike DeWine wore a protective mask made by his wife at a coronavirus briefing this month. His handling of the pandemic has led to a surge in his approval ratings.

item.title: Marc Benioff’s $25 Million Blitz to Buy Protective Gear From China
item.description: A call from a university chancellor set in motion a private-sector effort to procure 50 million masks, gowns and swabs for American medical facilities.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Matt Edge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marc Benioff, chief executive of Salesforce.

item.title: Abortion by Telemedicine: A Growing Option as Access to Clinics Wanes
item.description: The coronavirus has created a surge in demand for telemedicine of all types — including for a quietly expanding program for terminating pregnancies.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Michelle Mishina-Kunz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashley Dale taking medications that were mailed to her through an abortion telemedicine service.

item.title: Stocks Waver as Consumer Survey Shows Continued Concern: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: A Dongfeng Honda factory in Wuhan, China. Chinese factories are up and running again, but consumers aren’t spending much yet.

item.title: Live Tracker: World Coronavirus Coverage
item.description: Spain’s villages are waging a lonely fight against the virus, and volunteers in Belgium are risking infection to help homeless migrants.
item.media:description: Walking past posters of the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games in a subway station in Tokyo last week.

item.title: 2 Sought $4 Million for Face Masks That Didn’t Exist, U.S. Says
item.description: Two Southern California men face fraud charges after putting fake 3M labels on empty boxes that they said were filled with masks, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Various N95 respiration masks at a laboratory of 3M in Maplewood, Minn.

item.title: New York Attorney General Scrutinizes Amazon for Firing Warehouse Worker
item.description: The attorney general said in a letter that Amazon may have violated laws in firing a Staten Island worker who led a protest against the company.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:description: Amazon workers protesting on March 30 outside the company’s warehouse on Staten Island.

item.title: Trump Vows More Coronavirus Testing, but Less Than What May Be Needed
item.description: The president’s announcement came after weeks of him insisting that states had plenty of tests.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health care worker in the Bronx. Experts have recommended that anywhere from 0.9 percent to 50 percent of the American public be tested for the coronavirus every week.

item.title: Trump Disinfectant Remarks Echo Claims by Miracle-Cure Quacks
item.description: Doctors and public health officials fear the attention could boost purveyors of dangerous elixirs who push ‘miracle cures’ with no basis in science.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: President Trump during a presentation by NASA officials on their coronavirus projects at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Officials Say Limits on Virus Relief Funds for States Are Too Tight
item.description: Lawmakers and other officials are seeking more flexibility in spending federal emergency aid even as Republicans resist allocating more dollars.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction worker had his temperature taken before entering a construction site in New York last week.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A promising vaccine in development at Oxford University could be distributed as soon as September.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Trump's Coronavirus Briefings 'Not Worth the Time.' But He Couldn't Stay Away
item.description: Just hours after his own White House officially canceled his planned appearance on Monday, the lure of the cameras in the Rose Garden proved too hard to resist.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump in a meeting with industry executives about the coronavirus response at the White House on Monday. He then had them speak at his news briefing.

item.title: In Kayleigh McEnany, Trump Taps a Press Fighter for the Coronavirus Era
item.description: Kayleigh McEnany saw Donald J. Trump as her ticket to stardom. She has been fighting for him for much of her adult life, now as the president’s fourth press secretary.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since taking over as press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany has frequently defended President Trump on Fox News and Twitter, although she has yet to hold a news briefing.

item.title: Does the Biden Bump Have More to Do With Trump?
item.description: Polling in two states that many Democrats assumed were lost shows Joe Biden with a narrow lead over President Trump. But the race is moving toward Democrats for reasons that have very little to do with Mr. Biden.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
item.description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Saturday.

item.title: With Schools Shut by Coronavirus, Remote Learning Strains Parents
item.description: For the adults in the house, trying to do their own jobs while helping children with class work has become one of the most trying aspects of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: It has been challenging for Casey Schaeffer and Daniel Levin to manage the schooling of their children, Ramona and Linus.

item.title: Israelis and Palestinians Remember the Slain, Home Alone or Online En Masse
item.description: With Israel’s cemeteries closed, Memorial Day mourning had to adapt to the coronavirus lockdown. An alternative ceremony bringing together Israelis and Palestinians attracted 170,000 people online.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: An Israeli woman at home in the city of Ashkelon on Monday, Israel’s Memorial Day.

item.title: Job or Health? Restarting the Economy Threatens to Worsen Economic Inequality
item.description: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Birl Hicks, a small-business owner, in front of his store, Area 57, in Columbia, S.C. The state has begun allowing some businesses to reopen.
